To begin tracking you will need to create at least one track group. Track groups allow you to separate out groups of things you might want to track at the same time. For example you may wish to create one group for your exercise routine and another for food types.
Your track groups will appear in your list of groups. You can order them easily by holding down on the item you want to move and then dragging it to a new position.
Once you’ve created your track group select it and then click the + icon to set up something new to track.
Type in the name of what you want to track and select an input style:

There are two styles of input you can choose: 

• Numerical will ask you to enter a number when tracking. 

• Multiple choice requires you to manually set up predefined answers that will be presented to you as buttons when tracking.

If you add a default value you will not be asked for a value every time you tap the + button and your default value will be used instead. However you can go back and change the value by editing the data point afterwards (as explained later).
To create multiple choice answers click the + button at the bottom.
When you are happy with the setup click the FINISH button.
You should now see cards in your track group. You can order them easily by holding down on the item you want to move and then dragging it to a new position.
You can track things individually by using their + buttons or track everything in the group quickly by using the action button:
Don\'t worry if you make a mistake you can always see, review and edit your tracking history by simply tapping on the card.
To import/export your tracked data first select a track group and notice the menu buttons at the top:
Use this button to import a csv into this track group.
Use this button to export this track group to a csv.

Using the multiple choice input type is recommended wherever possible. If you ever want to draw a pie chart from your data you will need it to be in multiple choice form. You can also draw a line graph of your data over time if your predefined answers have a natural order. For example say you were to setup the following:
And then you tracked some data as follows:
You could then visualise that data using either a line graph over time or using a pie chart as below:

To begin creating graphs you will need to first have some data tracked. Then go to the home page and create a new graph group. Your graph groups do not have to align in any way with your track groups, you can organise them how you want.
Your graph groups will appear in your list of groups. You can order them easily by holding down on the item you want to move and then dragging it to a new position.
Once you’ve created your graph group select it and then click the + icon to set up a new graph or statistic.

Begin by entering a name for your new graph and then select a graph type. Here we will demonstrate the line graph since other graph types are relatively trivial to set up. One caveat to note however is that you can only create pie charts from multiple choice data.
Now we will add some lines to our graph by using the + button at the bottom:

Because our wheat values are multiple choice answers ranging from 0–2 and our stomach pain values are numbers ranging from 1–8 we have multiplied our wheat values by 4 to make the ranges similar. We have used a three day moving average to smooth out anomalies and reduce noise in the output graph. We have also selected plot when tracked because this data was tracked relatively consistently. You can read more about how these settings affect line graphs in the FAQ: “How are moving averages and plot totals calculated?”
Next we click the FINISH button to complete the setup. Notice how our new graph appears as a card in our graph group:
To explore the graph in more detail you can tap the card to open it in a full screen view and then pinch and drag the lines:
As we add more graphs and statistics to our graph group they appear as a list of cards. You can reorder them at any point by holding down and dragging a card to a new position.
Suppose we want to track something simply as a yes or no question, for example:
If we were to track this data over time without using a moving average it might look like this:
This output is very accurate but not very helpful. To make it easier to understand the data we could use a monthly moving average:
Now instead of plotting each data point with the recorded Y value (0 or 1), each Y value is calculated as the mean of itself and all previous data points within the selected time range prior.

Generally speaking the longer the selected averaging period the smoother the curve will appear. However note that moving averages are lagging indicators. The longer the averaging period, the further behind the real value the curve will lag.
Some things you may only want to track rarely. For example, you may want to track when you finish reading a book:
You may or may not then be surprised to find that your graph appears as follows:
The problem is that lines are drawn only from each plotted value to the next plotted value. Since all plotted values are interpreted as 1 you only see a straight line at the point 1 on the Y axis.
We can fix this using plot totals. For example if we plot monthly totals we would see the following graph:
Notice a point is plotted at the end of each month representing the total of all tracked values in that month.
You can use scale, offset, averaging and totals all at once. The order of precedence is as follows:

• First your data is converted to totals
• Then each point is converted to its moving average
• Then your points are multiplied by the scale value
• Finally the offset is added to each point

Backup saves all of your app data including all tracked data, graphs and reminders. You should back up your data to an external device or cloud storage regularly in case your device gets lost or broken.
WARNING: Restoring from a backup will erase all data and setup currently in the app. Track & Graph will restart after the restore is complete.

There is also a Backup & Restore option in the menu. This will export and restore the entire database file containing all tracked data, graphs, reminders etc. This is an un-encrypted Sqlite3 database file which can also be opened and modified using freely available software. However this is not recommended for non-technical users as you could break the integrity of the database.
